awd_titl_txt: Evolutionary Dynamics and Diversity in High Dimensions
awd_abstract_narration:
Extensive DNA sequencing has revealed a tremendous amount of genetic diversity within species, including fine-scale diversity within local populations of single bacterial species in nature, as well as in populations evolved from a single clone in the laboratory. Yet the causes and statistical properties of this diversity are far from understood, with the evolutionary processes of mutation, recombination, selection, stochastic fluctuations, and spatial dispersal all playing roles, as well as the ecological interactions between subtypes and changing environments. The complexities of the organisms and environments mean that the eco-evo dynamics takes place in high-dimensional space. The primary goal of this project is to study various aspects of the evolutionary and ecological dynamics focussing on the statistical properties of the diversity, including aspects not previously studied, that these give rise to. This will be done by developing and analyzing simple models, some rough approximations of the actual processes and others abstract caricatures that endeavor to make use of the high-dimensional aspects to extract general features. Laboratory experiments and data from natural microbial communities, some of which the PI has been and will continue to be involved with, will motivate some of the modeling and the predictions will be compared with sequencing and other data. The theory to be developed on the statistical consequences of genetic hitchhiking on selection elsewhere in the genome has the potential to enable better use of human genetic diversity data to infer evolutionary history, and other aspects, of human populations. The educational impacts include development of courses and curricula bringing together biology and the quantitative sciences as well as training of women students and postdocs. 

Better theory on the interplay between various sources of diversity and their observable consequences will advance both qualitative and quantitative understanding of short term microbial evolution. The project will focus on identifying statistical properties of genetic diversity that can most effectively distinguish between scenarios for evolutionary history and ecology when the phenotypic differences are subtle enough that they cannot be readily observed. This will enable more effective use of DNA sequencing data and motivate which types of data would be most informative for future studies. Likewise, it will will help motivate which laboratory experiments that combine evolutionary and ecological aspects experiments might shed most light on these complex processes. The modeling and analysis will involve developing some new statistical dynamical and asymptotic methods, as well as exploring the potential of crude caricature models to explore scenarios and develop intuition.

por.por_cntn:
The remarkable diversity of bacterial species has been revealed by the DNA sequencing revolution.  Far less well known ? and even more puzzling ? is that this diversity extends far below species level with multiple strains, sub-strains, and sub-sub-strains coexisting and directly competing in the same location. And laboratory experiments and some observations of natural populations have revealed that bacterial populations are not static but continually ? and often rapidly ? evolving, even in seemingly constant environments.   This project combined analysis of genetic diversity of two particular species with theoretical work to address basic questions motivated by these observations.  Why doesn?t ?survival of the fittest? lead to the few fittest strains driving the others locally ? or even globally ? extinct? And why does evolution in even carefully controlled environments continue fast enough to be observable?   

The fundamental starting point is that organisms ? even bacteria ? are very complex.  In large bacterial populations that have existed for a long time, any mutation that is always beneficial will have long ago arisen and swept through the population. Thus, any new mutations or other genetic changes that arise must either be harmful or be only sometimes beneficial, depending on interactions with other genes, with the particular environment, or with other strains and species.    The net effect of a mutation will thus be the sum of both negative and positive parts.  Following a long tradition in physics (initially nuclear physics), this suggests that a crude caricature of the complexities is to treat the effects of changes -- genetic or ecological ? as approximately ?random?.    A very simple model of an organism treats the complexities of the cell biology as a huge number of soft constraints on the interactions among combinations of its many proteins, and its interactions with its environment as simply a preferred ?direction? in the ?high-dimensional space? of all possible values of the protein properties.  Evolution gradually changes these properties. We show that after a single strain adapts quite well to its environment, any, even tiny, feedback of the evolution on the environment causes the evolution to continue forever without further slowing down. This surprising result is like the ?Red Queen? of Alice in Wonderland who has to run fast just to stay still.  

Coexistence of species is traditionally explained by the existence of many niches, with each competing more with its own species than with others.  But for closely related strains there is no reason competition with siblings is stronger than with third cousins. And this tends to lead to most strains going extinct.  We developed a new scenario for the coexistence of many strains: a diverse ecologically chaotic state in which each surviving strain has occasional blooms and busts that occur in one location, causing populations of other strains to rise and fall, and, later, blooms and busts at other locations.  This can occur in simple models of bacterial strains infected by many strains of a virus that attacks them.  And we show how this chaotic state evolves and become more diverse with time.  
Diversity in natural populations of two cyanobacterial species was studied using separately-sequenced genomes of hundreds of single cells (a recently developed technology). One species lives in Yellowstone hot springs (the green layer), and the other is Prochlorococcus, which is enormously abundant in tropical oceans and fixes more carbon from the atmosphere than all human croplands combined.   Bacteria were traditionally thought to reproduce almost entirely asexually, with only occasional transfers of segments of DNA from one cell to another. But our analyses (and recent work by others on different species) have revealed a very different picture: there is so much genetic exchange across each species that the genomes of individuals are more like those of humans, a mosaic of segments of DNA.  This raises the possibility that the key question for developing future understanding of bacterial intra-species diversity and evolution is not the diversity of genomes. But instead: What causes and maintains the diversity of each gene?  

The students and postdocs trained under this grant came from theoretical physics with little or no biology backgrounds and developed into top notch researchers with a broad and cutting edge base of expertise in genetic evolution, data analysis, theoretical modeling, and, most crucially, the ability to frame new questions that move well beyond traditional, or even current,  paradigms.  The PI has developed courses to teach evolution to non-biologists, and to teach quantitative reasoning to biology graduate students and postdocs, most recently using COVID from molecular to pandemic scales as an example.
